title: De-Pierre Map
text:
De-Pierre Map is an ancient <a href="map">map</a> of the city of <a href="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a> which was drawn by the <a href="Austrians">Austrian</a> <a href="pilgrim">pilgrim</a> De Pierre in 1728.
Today the map is found within the Eran Laor maps collection in the <a href="National%20Library%20of%20Israel">National Library of Israel</a> in Jerusalem.
Description.
The map provides a detailed description of the <a href="Old%20City%20%28Jerusalem%29">old city of Jerusalem</a>, with an accurate description of the <a href="Walls%20of%20Jerusalem">ancient city's wall</a> which was built by <a href="Suleiman%20the%20Magnificent">Suleiman the Magnificent</a>, of the <a href="Temple%20Mount">Temple Mount</a> structures, and of the <a href="Tower%20of%20David">Tower of David</a>. The structures surrounding the ancient city and the locations of the ancient city's streets are illustrated freely. The perspective onto the city is the view from the <a href="Mount%20of%20Olives">Mount of Olives</a> (namely from east to west). At the bottom of the map appears an illustration of the <a href="Jordan%20River">Jordan River</a>, and on the map's left side an illustration of the <a href="Dead%20Sea">Dead Sea</a> area.
The map also exhibits historical and <a href="Bible">biblical</a> events, such as <a href="Absalom">Avshalom</a> the son of Israeli king <a href="David">David</a> hanging from a tree, two of <a href="The%20Twelve%20Spies">The Twelve Spies</a> holding a cluster of grapes, the battle of David and <a href="Goliath">Goliath</a>, <a href="Abraham">Abraham</a>'s three visitors, and the <a href="Star%20of%20Bethlehem">Star of Bethlehem</a>.
The map was dedicated to <a href="emperor">empress</a> <a href="Elisabeth%20Christine%20of%20Brunswick-Wolfenb%C3%BCttel">Elisabeth Christine</a>, the wife of <a href="Charles%20VI%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Charles VI, Holy Roman Emperor</a>.
The dimension of the map is 84.3 by 53.4 centimeters.
